chapter.htmlHeader: What  investigations are advised in a woman with suspected pelvic inflammatory disease?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
A diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) should be made on clinical grounds. Do not delay making a diagnosis and initiating treatment whilst waiting for the results of laboratory tests. Negative swab results do not rule out a diagnosis of PID.

Consider referring the woman to a genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinic or other local specialist sexual health service to facilitate screening for infections and for contact tracing. 

  • Offer a pregnancy test to all sexually active women who are potentially fertile, to exclude ectopic pregnancy. See the CKS topic on Ectopic pregnancy.
  • Consider taking a high vaginal swab to exclude other vaginal infections, such as bacterial vaginosis and candidiasis. For more information, see the CKS topics on Bacterial vaginosis and Candida - female genital. 
  • Test for the following:
    • Chlamydia. See the section on Testing to confirm the diagnosis in the CKS topic on Chlamydia - uncomplicated genital for more information.
    • Gonorrhoea. See the section on Confirmation of diagnosis in the CKS topic on Gonorrhoea for more information.
    • Mycoplasma genitalium. Local availability of M. genitalium testing currently varies but implementation of testing is strongly recommended to guide the choice of appropriate treatment.
  • If possible, look for endocervical or vaginal pus cells under a microscope on a wet-mount vaginal smear.
    • If absent, a diagnosis of PID is unlikely.
    • Excess leucocytes are associated with PID, but they are also found in women with lower genital tract infection.
  • Consider performing the following tests (which if elevated support the diagnosis of PID but are non-specific):
    • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).
    • C-reactive protein.
    • Leucocyte count.
  • Offer blood tests for the following:
    • HIV. See the section on How to test for HIV in the CKS topic on HIV infection and AIDS.
    • Syphilis. See the section on Management of suspected syphilis in the CKS topic on Syphilis for more information.
  • Offer chlamydia screening to all sexually active people younger than 25 years of age, annually, or more frequently if they have changed their partner. See the CKS topic on Chlamydia - uncomplicated genital for more information.
  • Consider other investigations, as appropriate.
    • Ultrasound scanning is of limited value for uncomplicated PID but is helpful if an abscess or hydrosalpinx is suspected. Doppler ultrasound can detect increased blood flow associated with pelvic infection and may be useful, but it cannot differentiate between PID and other causes of increased vascularity, such as endometriosis.
    • MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) or CT (computed tomography) scanning of the pelvis may be helpful in differentiating PID from alternative diagnoses, but they are not indicated routinely.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based largely on the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) guideline 2018 United Kingdom national guideline for the management of pelvic inflammatory disease [BASHH, 2018] and the European guideline for the management of pelvic inflammatory disease [Ross, 2017].

Diagnosing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)

  • Expert opinion in the BASHH guideline is that [BASHH, 2018]:
    • A diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) should be considered (and usually empirical antibiotic treatment offered) in any sexually active woman who has recent onset lower abdominal pain associated with local tenderness on bimanual vaginal examination, in whom pregnancy has been excluded and no other cause for the pain has been identified.
    • The diagnosis of PID based only on positive examination findings, in the absence of lower abdominal pain, should only be made with caution.

Testing for gonorrhoea, chlamydia, and Mycoplasma genitalium

  • Testing for gonorrhoea, chlamydia, and M. genitalium in the lower genital tract is recommended because a positive result supports the diagnosis of PID and may alter subsequent treatment, although a negative result does not exclude PID [BASHH, 2018]. 

Interpreting the results of a wet-mount smear

  • The absence of endocervical or vaginal pus cells suggests that the diagnosis is not PID, but their presence is non-specific [Ross, 2017; BASHH, 2018].
    • The negative predictive value for a diagnosis of PID is high (among those who had a negative test result, the probability of being disease-free is 95%).
    • The positive predictive value is low (among those who have a positive test result, the probability of disease is only 17%).

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein, and leucocyte count

  • An elevated ESR, C-reactive protein, and leucocyte count supports the diagnosis of PID but is non-specific. Levels are usually only abnormal in moderate or severe PID [Ross, 2017; BASHH, 2018].

Offering blood tests for HIV and syphilis

  • This recommendation is based on the Public Health England (PHE) guideline Management and laboratory diagnosis of Abnormal Vaginal Discharge: Quick Reference Guide for Primary Care [PHE, 2013], the BASHH UK national guideline for the management of gonorrhoea in adults [BASHH, 2011], and the BASHH UK national guideline for the management of infection with Chlamydia trachomatis [BASHH, 2015], which recommend offering blood tests for HIV and syphilis if testing for gonorrhoea and chlamydia.

Offering an annual chlamydia screen to women younger than 25 years

  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in the PHE guideline [PHE, 2013] and the BASHH guideline on the management of chlamydia [BASHH, 2015].
